entries.title: Illinois Governor, Sheriffs Spar Over Semiautomatic Gun Law
entries.description: Springfield, Ill. (AP) -- To the scores of sheriffs in Illinois who reportedly have vowed not to enforce the ban on semiautomatic weapons that took effect this week, Gov. J.B. Pritzker has a succinct answer: Yes, you will.

entries.title: Lawmakers Demand Answers for Flight Halt in Letter to Buttigieg
entries.description: A bipartisan group of more than 100 House lawmakers is demanding that Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg provide answers to Wednesday’s air-traffic shutdown, which they called “completely unacceptable.”

entries.title: China Finds No New Covid Variants But Mutation Threat Lingers
entries.description: China has yet to detect any dangerous Covid mutations in the six weeks since the virus was unleashed on the country’s 1.4 billion people after the abandonment of the rigid curbs that held the pathogen largely at bay.

entries.title: Trump Calls Rape Claim, Climate Change ‘Hoaxes’ in Deposition
entries.description: Donald Trump Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

entries.title: Trump’s 2016 Campaign Settles Nondisclosure-Agreement Fight
entries.description: Former President Donald Trump’s 2016 campaign has reached a settlement in a long-running fight over its nondisclosure agreements that would free potentially hundreds of ex-staffers, contractors and volunteers to say what they want to about their experience.

entries.title: Biden’s Winning Streak Hit by Classified Documents Probe
entries.description: President Joe Biden began the year with a surge of political momentum, propelled by better-than-expected midterm election results and Republican disarray.

entries.title: Supreme Court to Consider Expanding Rights of Religious Workers
entries.description: The US Supreme Court agreed to consider requiring employers to do more to accommodate the needs of religious workers, accepting an appeal from a Pennsylvania postal carrier who says he was forced out of his job for refusing to work on Sundays.

entries.title: Austin Starts Program to Help Fly Asylum Seekers Out of Texas
entries.description: AUSTIN, TEXAS - NOVEMBER 06: General view of atmosphere during the Austin FOOD & WINE Festival at Auditorium Shores on November 06, 2022 in Austin, Texas. (Photo by Rick Kern/Getty Images)

entries.title: Brazil Prosecutors Request Bolsonaro Probe for Inciting Riot
entries.description: Rio De Janeiro (AP) -- The Brazilian prosecutor-general's office on Friday asked the Supreme Court to include former president Jair Bolsonaro in its investigation into who incited the Jan. 8 riot in the nation's capital.

entries.title: Chicago Mayoral Candidate Garcia Puts Crime at Heart of Race
entries.description: US Representative Jesus “Chuy” Garcia is making public safety in Chicago a top priority for his mayoral campaign as he seeks to replace incumbent Lori Lightfoot.

entries.title: Yellen, Powell Compromised on a Comma as They Vied for Fed Chair
entries.description: As Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen and Governor Jerome Powell vied in 2017 over who’d head the central bank in the future, they moved in lockstep behind the scenes on monetary policy – except when it came to the placement of a comma.

entries.title: Biden Covid-19 Adviser Kessler to Depart as Pandemic Wanes
entries.description: David Kessler, a former FDA commissioner who helped steer President Joe Biden’s Covid-19 policy, will leave the administration — a sign of the government’s waning response to the pandemic.

entries.title: Biden to Give State of the Union Feb. 7 as Debt Fight Looms
entries.description: President Joe Biden has accepted House Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s invitation to deliver the State of the Union address on Feb. 7.

entries.title: Veteran Lawyer Bob Bauer Is Representing Biden on Documents Review
entries.description: Longtime Democratic attorney Bob Bauer is the personal lawyer representing President Joe Biden on the classified documents investigation, according to the White House.

entries.title: What’s the Debt Ceiling, and Will the US Raise It?
entries.description: The very phrase “debt ceiling” sounds austere and restrictive, as if it’s a lid on government spending. In fact, the US federal debt limit was first conceived more than a century ago to make it easier, not harder, for the government to borrow money. But it morphed into an explosive political tool with the potential to roil financial markets, since a failure to raise the debt ceiling could eventually result in a first-ever default on some of the government’s obligations.

entries.title: Britain’s Housing Market Is Flashing Red, and Sunak’s Tories Are Scared
entries.description: Tory voters are worried about mounting crime, taxes and the National Health Service. But MPs say a real estate slump may be the biggest danger for the prime minister

entries.title: Two Special Counsels for Two Presidents: Breaking Down the Differences
entries.description: The two special counsels appointed by Attorney General Merrick Garland have basically the same assignment: Exploring whether anyone — including a current or former president — criminally mishandled sensitive government information.

entries.title: Trump Must Face Suit Under NY Sexual Assault Law, Judge Says
entries.description: Donald Trump Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

entries.title: Yellen Says US to Take Extraordinary Steps to Avert a Default
entries.description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the department will begin taking special accounting maneuvers on Jan. 19 to avoid breaching the US debt limit, urging lawmakers to boost the ceiling to avert a devastating payments default.

entries.title: German Army Stands by Puma Vehicle Despite Technical Failures
entries.description: Germany’s military will continue to use the Puma armored fighting vehicle, despite recent technical failures, Defense Minister Christine Lambrecht said.

entries.title: What to Know About Netanyahu’s Far-Right Government in Israel: QuickTake
entries.description: Benjamin Netanyahu was sworn in Dec. 29 for a sixth time as Israel’s prime minister, in a right-wing coalition in which his Likud Party is the most moderate member. Once-fringe, far-right politicians are now a key part of the government. Though Netanyahu has pledged to rein in extremism, there are risks that the new government’s actions will deepen tensions with Palestinians, erode Israel’s democracy, and strain relations with the country’s neighbors and allies, including the US.

entries.title: Storms Show California’s Outdated Plumbing Puts Economy at Risk
entries.description: Even as rains drench the fields and orchards in California’s Central Valley where Bill Diedrich grows pistachios, almonds, tomatoes, cotton and other crops, he is still calculating losses from the region’s other defining extreme: severe drought.

entries.title: SEC Awards Whistleblower Over $5 Million for Enforcement Help
entries.description: The US Securities and Exchange Commission awarded more than $5 million to a whistleblower who the agency says helped it bring a successful enforcement action.

entries.title: Sweden Calls Erdogan Effigy an Attempt to Sabotage Its NATO Bid
entries.description: Sweden’s government said the hanging of an effigy of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Stockholm was a deliberate attempt to block the Nordic nation’s efforts to become a member of the NATO alliance.

entries.title: MTN Gets $773 Million Tax Bill in Ghana It ‘Strongly Disputes’
entries.description: MTN Group Ltd., Africa’s largest wireless carrier, said it’s received a $773 million back-tax bill, including penalties and interest charges, in Ghana that it plans to fight.

entries.title: Summers Says Recession Still Looms, Fed Getting Closer to Done
entries.description: Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers said that the US economy is still facing a recession this year, despite encouraging news in recent weeks.

entries.title: George Santos Says Everyone Lies on Their Résumé. He’s Not Lying.
entries.description: The New York politician is under fire for falsehoods that recruitment experts say should have been discovered. But resume fakery is rampant in the corporate world as well.

entries.title: Germany Closes In on a Decision to Send Leopard Tanks to Ukraine
entries.description: Germany will make a decision on sending Leopard battle tanks to Ukraine in the next week, as European allies assess how to help the government in Kyiv in the event fighting builds in the spring.

entries.title: The Strikes That Could Bring More Chaos to Britain
entries.description: Enjoy your weekend — it’ll be the first without major strikes since early December, if you live in the UK.

entries.title: UK Closes In on Deal to End Rail Strikes Crippling Commuters
entries.description: A deal may be in sight between UK rail unions and train-operating companies to draw to a close months of crippling rail strikes, government officials familiar with the matter said.

entries.title: Campaign to Renew US Spy Powers Faces Bitter Battle in Congress
entries.description: The US intelligence community faces a hard battle to renew foreign surveillance powers that have enabled authorities to repeatedly access private information about Americans despite constitutional protections.

entries.title: Buttigieg’s Post-Biden Ambitions Dented by Travel Meltdown
entries.description: A series of transportation calamities is tarnishing Pete Buttigieg’s political prospects, threatening to hamper his ability to use his high-profile cabinet position as a springboard for a widely-expected second White House bid once President Joe Biden leaves office.

entries.title: Global Debt Racing to 366% of Output Risks Next Crisis, S&P Warns
entries.description: The world is at risk of a crisis as governments, households and financial institutions binge on debt, a habit that S&P Global Ratings warns could push overall leverage to 366% of global gross domestic product by 2030.

entries.title: Russia Claims Donbas Town But Ukraine Says It’s in Control
entries.description: Russia claimed Moscow’s troops had taken Soledar, a small town in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, in one of their first victories in months. Kyiv rejected the claim.

entries.title: Brexit Customs Deal Close With UK-EU Talks Poised to Intensify
entries.description: The UK and European Union are nearing an agreement on customs aimed at reducing trade friction between Great Britain and Northern Ireland as they prepare to intensify wider post-Brexit negotiations.

entries.title: Poland Says Iran Releases Its Scientist Detained on Spy Charges
entries.description: Iran has freed a Polish university professor detained in September 2021, according to the Polish Foreign Ministry.

entries.title: Austrian Finance Minister in Hospital After E-Scooter Accident
entries.description: Austria’s Finance Minister Magnus Brunner was hospitalized after an E-scooter accident late Thursday, a spokesman said by email.

entries.title: EU Eyes Easing Curbs on State Aid for Clean Tech in Reply to US
entries.description: The European Union is considering easing restrictions on state aid for clean tech products, as the bloc seeks to support companies and counter a US climate law.

entries.title: White-Collar Jobs and Service Workers Are New Union Hotbeds
entries.description: While organized labor has stalled in manufacturing, it’s gaining ground in restaurants, delivery companies and white-collar workplaces.

entries.title: President Lula’s Brazil Budget Math Doesn’t Add Up for Investors
entries.description: The new government needs to present a clear plan for bringing public debt under control.

entries.title: ‘Doomsday Clocks’ Likely Needed Before Congress Hikes Debt Limit
entries.description: With the US government facing the danger of a payments default later this year, Congress has a variety of paths to avert economic disaster and boost the debt ceiling.

entries.title: ‘Taxachusetts’ Revived in New England After Millionaire Surtax
entries.description: Tax advisers have long said it’s inadvisable to die in Massachusetts — one of the least generous states for estate levies — but now it may also be worth thinking again about living there.

entries.title: US Supreme Court Waits, and Waits Some More, to Issue First Opinion
entries.description: The US Supreme Court is certain to end its current term with fireworks given pending cases over affirmative action, election law, social media and student loans.

entries.title: Biden Stumbles Into a Crisis of His Own Making
entries.description: Joe Biden was feeling pretty good at the start of 2023. He had a string of legislative wins in his pockets and Republicans had just made a spectacle of themselves electing a speaker of the House.

entries.title: Imran Khan Dissolving Regional Assemblies to Push Pakistan Polls
entries.description: Allies of Pakistan’s former premier Imran Khan are moving to dissolve two of the four provincial assemblies in a bid to force Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif to call for national elections well before November.

entries.title: Polish Parliament Takes First Step to Back Bill Accessing EU Aid
entries.description: A bill that promises to give Poland’s government access to billions of euros in European Union aid cleared its first hurdle on Friday after the ruling party secured a majority in parliament to push on with the legislation.

entries.title: Lula's Ties With Military Are Strained by Crackdown on Rioters
entries.description: By criticizing his army commanders, Brazilian president risks undermining his own efforts to mend relations with generals

entries.title: Trump Firm’s Criminal Punishment Carries Threats Beyond Sentence
entries.description: The two Trump companies found guilty of criminal tax fraud last month face sentencing on Friday, but the real punishment lies in the blowback to the former president’s business that is likely to go on for years.

entries.title: Union Lawyer’s Fight Against Tegna Deal Helps Its Corporate Foes
entries.description: A union lawyer arguing that the $5.4 billion purchase of broadcaster Tegna Inc. by hedge fund Standard General LP will corrode democracy and should be blocked is also a lobbyist for three companies that stand to benefit financially if the deal dies.

entries.title: Fighting Rages in Ukraine, Biden Faces Crisis: The Political Week in Photos
entries.description: Fierce battles between Russian and Ukrainian forces raged close to the towns of Soledar and Bakhmut in the eastern Donetsk region as Moscow sought to score victories after suffering months of setbacks in its invasion.

entries.title: UK Treasury Adviser Lombardelli Named as OECD Chief Economist
entries.description: Clare Lombardelli, chief economic adviser at the U.K. Treasury, poses for a photograph in London, U.K., on Tuesday, July 24, 2018. One of the key officials involved in choosing Bank of England policy makers has pushed back against criticism that the central bank has too few women at the top.

entries.title: Ethiopia Eurobond Yields Plunge on Tigray Peace Deal Progress
entries.description: Ethiopian eurobonds rallied after dissident Tigrayan fighters this week agreed to hand over heavy weapons, firming up a peace deal that may bring an end to the country’s civil war, and after China agreed to cancel some of its bilateral debt.

entries.title: Ukraine Latest: Italy Offers Use of Logistics, Ports to Kyiv
entries.description: Italy offered use of its logistics infrastructure, including the Adriatic Sea ports of Venice and Trieste, for Ukraine’s exports, Industry Minister Adolfo Urso said in an interview Friday. Urso had met with President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and other Ukrainian officials in Kyiv on Thursday.

entries.title: Japan Indicts Suspected Killer of Former Premier Abe
entries.description: Japanese prosecutors indicted a man in his 40s on charges of fatally shooting former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe last year in a crime that horrified the country and triggered a scandal over the ruling party’s links with a fringe religion.

entries.title: Things to Know as Davos Returns in Winter Amid ‘Polycrisis’ Risk
entries.description: A wooden sign on the waterfront of Lake Davos in Davos, Switzerland, on Sunday, Jan. 8, 2023. Though it’s perched at an altitude of 1,560 meters, this year’s rare winter heatwave saw the Swiss town of Davos basking in temperatures well above freezing in early January, with its mountainsides covered in dead, brown grass and hikers out with their dogs.

entries.title: War Turns Sleepy Polish City Into World’s Gateway to Ukraine
entries.description: Rzeszow is known for its role in the aeronautics industry. Now it’s playing a key part in the effort to thwart Vladimir Putin.

entries.title: Hottest EM Bond Trade Set for Reality Check When Turkey Votes
entries.description: Turkey’s election this year threatens to reverse one of the best trades in credit.

entries.title: How Far Apart Are the UK and EU on a Brexit Deal?
entries.description: The UK and European Union are poised to enter the final stretch of negotiations over post-Brexit trading arrangements for Northern Ireland. After years of distrust and tension both sides are optimistic that a settlement is within reach.

entries.title: Putin Buys Off the Poor, Writes Off Middle Class With War Budget
entries.description: Alexei Malov’s dream was to own a white Lada.

entries.title: Titans of Italy’s Economy Await Fate as Meloni Reshapes Elite
entries.description: A chance for Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni to leave her mark on the economy is looming as a multitude of top jobs come up for renewal — including the governorship of the central bank.

entries.title: South Korea Calls for 24 to Be Charged Over Deadly Crowd Crush
entries.description: A South Korean panel referred 24 officials to prosecutors to face charges of professional negligence resulting in death over a crowd crush incident at a nightlife district in Seoul last October, which left 158 people dead.

entries.title: Malaysia Deputy PM Puts Faith in His Party Over Leadership Vote
entries.description: Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi said he would let his party decide whether his presidency should be open for contest, a move that could destabilize Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim’s coalition government.

entries.title: Japan Seeks Biden Endorsement of Security Overhaul at Summit
entries.description: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida will seek public support for his robust new security strategy from US President Joe Biden at their upcoming summit, after criticism from China.
